div.p: See also M's second letter to S. Robertson, written later the same day. 14/2/90

I deem it my duty, dear Mr Robertson, to draw your attention to the two following paragraphs
M enclosed the following two clippings with his letter:
'The Minister of Agriculture having failed to obtain any answer from the Australasian Association for the Advancement of Science in reply to his request that that body should appoint delegates to an intercolonial conference to consider the question of rust in wheat and the best method of preventing it, has written to the Governments of the colonies of South Australia, New South Wales, and Queensland asking them to appoint representatives. The Commissioner of Lands in South Australia has accepted the invitation. The Queensland Government has also intimated its intention to send representatives, but no reply has yet been received from New South Wales. It is intended to hold the conference in Melbourne in the first week in March.' (Argus, 13 February 1890).
'The Minister of Agriculture has arranged for an intercolonial conference of experts, to be held at Melbourne on the 1st of next month, to investigate the cause of rust in wheat, with the view of ascertaining whether growers could be protected against the great loss which they sustained. New South Wales, South Australia, Queensland and Victoria will each send two representatives to the conference, one a scientific and the other a practical man.' (Age, 13 February 1890). . Perhaps a letter is awaiting Prof Spencer's
Walter Baldwin Spencer. return. If so. it would be well for you, to simply acknowledge meanwhile the letter, particularly so, as the Vict. Government by so munificent a grant supported the Melbourne meeting of the Australian Association
The Australasian Association for the Advancement of Science. W. Spencer was Honorary Secretary of the Association's recently completed Congress in Melbourne, while Robertson was employed as his assistant. .
